fields.description:
Currently the Cherry Pick command also commits immediately. Would it be possible to optionally cherry-pick and not commit (I believe this is the equivalent of "git cherry-pick -n <SHA1>"?

Thanks.
fields.summary: Support cherry-pick without commit

fields.description:
To reproduce:
# Open hg repo in SourceTree, note bookmarks, switch to log view
# Drop to the command line, execute 'hg bookmark -r somerev testbookmark'
# Switch back to SourceTree, note that no refresh occurs, you have to press Cmd-R to see the new bookmark

Expected: auto-refresh behaviour.

Probably we're filtering out that kernel event by accident in order to avoid unnecessary refreshes.
fields.summary: Creating a Mercurial bookmark on the command line doesn't auto-refresh

fields.description: the only reason i still use GitX for browsing my git log is the default font size. It's hard to quickly scan the commit messages on SourceTree. Can you increase the log view font size on the next version or give an option to do that?
fields.summary: Increase default font size for log view

fields.description:
Hi, loving SourceTree since I discovered it (and Atlassian products for years).
SourceTree replaced GitX instantly for my daily use.

But there are two features of GitX that I'm missing, so I'm creating two issues there, hoping for them :)
Sorry if I'm duplicating an issue that I missed searching, or worse If I missed the feature in SourceTree.

The second feature:
In GitX, in the "Commit view" when you check the "Amend" checkbox, the "staged changes" area is populated with previous commit changes.
That way you can use amend to remove code from a previous commit, instead of "just" adding code like SourceTree does.
fields.summary: Amend a commit being able to edit what was previously commited

fields.description:
Hi, loving SourceTree since I discovered it (and Atlassian products for years).
SourceTree replaced GitX instantly for my daily use.

But there are two features of GitX that I'm missing, so I'm creating two issues there, hoping for them :)
Sorry if I'm duplicating an issue that I missed searching, or worse If I missed the feature in SourceTree.

The first feature:
In GitX, in the "history view" you can enable the "tree view" and then, browse all "source tree" at given time (commit) That's very handy.
I'm surprised I didn't find something similar in SourceTree. Maybe I missed something?
I know I could pick a file from "File Staging View" > "Show All" > show log >  look for a date... but... not really convenient.

A common use case is "what my code was at [tag-v2]"
fields.summary: Browse older version of source tree

fields.description:
Requested here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/54861/how-can-i-create-a-branch-in-sourcetree-git-from-arbitrary-commit

Equivalent to 'git branch <name> <SHA>'. 

Still some questions over exact use case, whether we should default to checking out the new branch or whether the reason it would be used was because the user didn't want to check out first.
fields.summary: Create branch at commit

fields.description: The dialog for "Git push" should respect my configured value for {{push.default}} (I have it set to {{current}}).
fields.summary: Git push should respect "git config push.default"

fields.description:
Intended action:
Amend the commit message for the last commit.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Make a commit for some changes
2. Put at least one other change in the stage index
3. Select "Commit" from the toolbar
4. Select "Amend latest commit" in the lower left corner of the commit dialog
5. Select "Selected files" for Commit mode
6. Unselect all files
7. Change commit message
8. Press "Commit"

Result:
All files in the stage index are committed along with the changed commit message. The stage index is empty.

Expected Result:
Changed commit message for the last commit and unchanged stage index.
fields.summary: "Amend latest commit" commits unselected files in stage index

fields.description:
Related issue: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1004

Currently although you can integrate with Bitbucket / Github via the hosted projects window, the integration is one-way - you can derive clone links and open the project website from the hosted projects window, but once you have the cloned repository that link is basically lost. It would be nice to retain or derive a link somehow so that useful features could be provided from within the repository window for remotes, such as:

* Open project on [insert host]
* View commit on [insert host]

We don't want to simply derive this by taking the details from the hosted projects window and copying them on clone, because the user might change the remote details later, or may have set up the repository from outside hosted projects (e.g. command line clone imported to SourceTree). Also you can have multiple remotes, so each of the above should probably be scoped with the remote name in the case that there are multiple remotes.

We can derive this linkage from a remote URL quite easily in the case of Bitbucket and GitHub, since the URLs are recognisable. In the case of hosts where the URL can be customised by the user, such as Stash and Kiln, this is more difficult; we would need some indicator against the remote which told us what type of hosting service it is. The difficult thing there is to keep this in sync with separate remote changes.

So initially, just supporting Bitbucket and GitHub would be best (and perhaps Kiln hosted at a kilnhg.com subdomain).
fields.summary: Extended integration with primary remotes

fields.description:
A Japanese user tweeted, "SourceTree has some mistranslations in Japanese..."Rebase current changes onto 'branch'" is translated into "The change of the electric rebase current onto 'branch'". Or "Parents" is translated into "Mother and Father"...
Please let me know even if there are the slightest changes. I'd like to help you. If you have time, will you send me the latest language files for translation?
fields.summary: Yet another mistranslation in Japanese?

fields.description:
If a SourceTree customer is also using gitolite on OS X for instance, and sets up ~/.ssh/config with a host called "gitolite", so he gets to specify his URLs like "gitolite:testing" in the "Source Path / URL" field of SourceTree when adding a repository. 

When he does that, the autofilled Clone dialog becomes:
Source Path/URL: gitolite:testing Destination Path: /Users/imagexpertinc/gitolite:testing Bookmark name: gitolite:testing
But the resulting directory shows up as "gitolite/testing" in the Mac Finder, and as "gitolite:testing" in Terminal.app. 
(also see attachement)
This is confusing for the customer, so he is requesting to have the autocomplete to fill in the "Destination Path" to something like "/Users/imagexpertinc/gitolite_testing so that the Finder and Terminal.app also shows "gitolite_testing" (so to check for a colon in the URL and replace it with maybe a "_" in the fields to which the URL is copied)
In the meantime, the workaround of manually updating ":" with "_" in the "Destination Path" field works.
fields.summary: Clone a repository that contains colon in its url name

fields.description: Make option to ignore SSL certificate problem while using repo with self-signed certificate
fields.summary: Make option to ignore SSL certificate problem

fields.description:
1. Create a new repository
2. Update a file
3. Stage the file
4. Commit a file
5. Notice that the Author and Committer are combined
6. Realize that the email settings for the SourceTree user are wrong. Change them from the Settings/Advanced panel for the project.

7. Amend the commit, notice that the author name is wrong, edit there again: Click Commit, select "Amend latest commit". Update the Author field.

8. Commit is updated with original author name (so not updated with the new Author name) and with the new committer name (that was set in settings/advanced)


Conclusion => It seems that once a commit is made, the author can not be updated via "Amend latest commit"

However, there is no problem for the "Committer". This field is amended accordingly if it is updated from Settings/Advanced panel for the project.


Workaround:

Update the Author from the command line: git commit --amend --author="First Last <name@domain.com>"

Commit is then updated correctly and SourceTree reflects that.
fields.summary: Committed "Author" is not updated via the "Amend latest commit"

fields.description: It would be nice, if there was an option to revert the draft commit message with cmd+z and cmd+shift+z.
fields.summary: Enable cmd+z and cmd+shif+z options in draft commit message

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a checkbox in the commit view (or a prompt when the commit fails, due to pre-commit hooks) to force the commit (-n flag)

GitX (http://gitx.laullon.com/) has this option.

Example of how this works on the command line:

$ git commit -m "Added Readme file"
Pre-Commit message hook failed!
$ git commit -nm "Added Readme file"
[master 2db5767] Added Readme file
 1 files changed, 1 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 README
$
fields.summary: Force commit

fields.description: It would be nice if we could right click on a commit and create a branch in git from a any commit in the log view. Currently it only lets you checkout a commit with a detached head, which is not so useful.
fields.summary: Create a branch from any commit in the log view

fields.description:
Here is my steps:

1. create a "feature" by git flow in Terminal
2. finish it by git flow
3. go to ST, current branch is switched to "develop"
4. right click on sidebar, choose "push to origin/develop (tracked)"

After the push window's closed, there's still an "ahead" signal.
And it's not pushed to server successfully.

But I can use the "push" button on toolbar to push to server.
fields.summary: ST can't push to server by sidebar menu with git flow

fields.description:
Start with a clean SourceTree install and run the set-up wizard.
I can't connect to Bit Bucket even with correct user/pass.
fields.summary: Can't set-up BitBucket account with SourceTree 1.4

fields.description:
It appears that some people do leave multiple old abandoned heads for a branch in Mercurial and don't merge or strip them. These people find the display of those heads in the sidebar annoying, because they don't actually want to resolve them. I think this is the minority case, because having these multiple heads makes pushing difficult in most cases, but we should support that usage mode.

The best way to do that is to use a preferences option which toggles whether to include multiple heads or not. It should default to YES.
fields.summary: Add Mercurial preference to not display multiple heads per branch in sidebar

fields.description:
Not sure whether this is intended behaviour, but changing the "Action after pull" setting in the drop-down sheet for a particular pull operation also changes this setting in SourceTree's global Preferences (as seen in the "Mercurial" tab of the Preferences window).

Rationale:  I generally want to update after a pull *unless* I'm pulling from Subversion, in which case I want to rebase.  If I set the post-pull action to rebase for a particular repository when I'm pulling from Subversion, it's easy not to notice the next time I'm pulling from Mercurial that it's still set to rebase, leading to unexpected and unwanted results.
fields.summary: Pull sheet sets "Action after pull" globally

fields.description:
I was hoping to use the 'Commit Text Replacements' feature to allow me to link my Bitbucket or Github repo to that specific commit.  This way we're able to work collaboratively with online tools.  

The issues is that there is no way to append the SHA of the commit to the message with a commit-msg hook because the SHA is created as part of the message.  I was going to use such an approach to link the SHA to an external service like Bitbucket or GitHub.

An alternative would be to bind the repo to the external service and/or realize this per remotes and all the Commit: sha in the log message to act as the link.
fields.summary: SHA Link to external Git hosting

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/52375/external-diff-doesn-t-work-when-comparing-a-local-repository-vs-a-remote?page=1#52419

When you compare a git remote branch with the current version and then use the main menu Actions > External Diff, nothing happens. The button in the diff panel works.
fields.summary: External diff on top-level menu doesn't work when comparing git remote branch

fields.description:
Related discussion: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/52092/sourcetree-hides-history-while-refreshing

Conclusion: it would be good to be able to maintain the content of the log view while refreshing. Although we're being cautious here to try to avoid allowing a user to click on something that may no longer exist (history editing conditions for example), it would be great to find graceful ways to tolerate this kind of edge case rather than avoid it entirely with the heavier-handed approach.
fields.summary: Try to maintain log view content more often under refresh conditions

fields.description:
I recorded a screencast showing the bug: https://vimeo.com/41498155

If you need more specific data or the full repository in it's current state, just let me know.
fields.summary: Log view broken due to wrong "git log" invocation

fields.description:
It would be awesome if SourceTree would allow quick cloning of existing repositories that it knows about -- either via the Bookmarks window (for example, in the contextual menu) or in repository's window itself.

My particular use case is quick creation of backups. I like to clone my repos to another local location, and then keep both the original and the backup in SourceTree's Bookmarks list.
fields.summary: Quick cloning of local repositories

fields.description: We have the policy that commit messages cannot exceed a certain line width. For that I'd like to be able to define a maximum line width and get some visual marker which helps me adhering to that policy.
fields.summary: Marker for preset commit message line width

fields.description: As commit messages tend to be long in our projects, I'd like to have handle for making the commit message area bigger (higher). And if possible let ST remember that height for my next commit message ...
fields.summary: Make commit message window height adjustable

fields.summary: SourceTree crashes

fields.description:
You just "improved" the bookmarks window and now it is unreadable. When I look at it, here's what I see:
  master
  master
  master
  master
  ...

That's because my relatively short repo names are just about the same size and are easily lost next to the GIT icon. What stands out, is the branch information to the right. This means I have to actually scan down the list of repos to find what I'm looking for rather than having it jump out at me. And I only have 11 repos. It must be awful for people with more.

The previous bookmarks window might have had less information it, but it was far more usable. I suggest you double the font size of the repo name and move the version information to the right.
fields.summary: The "new, improved" bookmarks window is less readable and usable

fields.description:
Twitter user @chrisyipw has volunteered to do a Chinese translation. 

Base translation files: http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/SourceTree_translation_base_1.4.zip
fields.summary: Chinese translation
Display SEN when viewing registration details

fields.description:
When a commit is created, the focus of the window is initially on the "Sign off" checkmark. Usually what you want however is to type in a commit message. 

CURRENT:
When the user starts typing right away after he pressed the commit button, he currently gets an warning sound and no text appears in the commit message (since the focus is on the sign off checkmark and that item doesn't understand the text entered).

EXPECTED:
The focus should be on the commit message textbox when the commit button is pressed.
fields.summary: Textfield should have focus when commit window is shown

fields.description:
At the moment, SourceTree only remembers window settings (size, position, split view settings, view options etc) if you bookmark a repository. For people that do not use the bookmarks window, but open repositories only through the command line or Finder, it would be useful to store default settings so that their preferences are remembered, even if only one set for all non-bookmarked repositories.

This would be fairly easy to implement by just using a dummy name for the settings which is used anywhere there isn't a real bookmark identifier.
fields.summary: Store default window settings for non-bookmarked repositories

fields.description:
Originally raised from: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-989

When the sidebar selection is already set to branch X, but you move the log view scroll position, you can't navigate back to that branch without changing the sidebar selection away from the current selection and back again. It should be possible to click again on the already-selected item to navigate back again. 

Requires either changing the sidebar not to keep its selection, or tracking clicks separately to changes in selection.
fields.summary: Clicking an already-selected branch in the sidebar should switch the log view to that revision too

fields.description:
In the log view, selecting a branch in the sidebar does NOT reliably reposition the log view to make that changeset visible.

This happens, for example, when the branch is right-clicked and updated to and sometimes when the branch is very far down when we update to it.

Also, if a branch is current but the log view doesn't show it (scrolled away), selecting, or double clicking on, the branch in the side-bar doesn't reveal it in the log view, whereas selecting another branch and then selecting the current one again DOES reposition the log view. This is silly and irritating.

This is most obvious when a repository has a large number of changesets and a complex graph.
fields.summary: Update To branch in sidebar doesn't relocate log view

fields.description:
SourceTree Log view is not very usable with large numbers of branches/changesets with complex dependencies.  Improvements to the UI would go a long way to putting this right.

1. Have a way of searching for a branch by partial match (could incorporate this into the Jump to: field fairly easily: dynamic/selective drop-down like gmail label searching).
2. Sort branch list (in left pane) most recent first (same order as log). Most times I'm looking for a recent branch and this is furthest away!
3. When selecting a branch in list - move view log to that branch immediately (even if already there - for visibility).
4. Highlight the ancestors of the current branch in the graph part of the log view.

Incidentally, selecting a branch doesn't always take the log view top the branch -- even if I Update To that branch. But this is clearly a bug; I'll file it.
fields.summary: Better usability for large numbers of changesets and branches

fields.description:
As pointed out here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/51973/how-to-view-git-tag-message

In the 'Advanced' section you can assign a message to the annotated tag, but this isn't in fact displayed anywhere in the SourceTree interface. If you can create it, you should be able to see it.
fields.summary: Display messages associated with git tags

fields.description:
Hi

This hotkey is Critical for making fast commits without using a mouse. Please add it.
fields.summary: Provide hotkey for "Add / Remove"

fields.description:
The problem is that when Sparkle installs the new version of SourceTree, it does not trigger Launch Services to update its database. This is usually done automatically when either:

# An application is installed via Finder (manual install of beta / first install)
# On reboot if an application is discovered that is new

Unfortunately Sparkle doesn't trigger either of these hooks because the app already existed and the install didn't go via Finder. We didn't spot this before release because anyone installing a preview build or beta version used Finder to install it, which triggers the Launch Services database update.

A manual way to regenerate the Launch Services database is to run this on the command line: 

{noformat}
/System/Library/Frameworks/CoreServices.framework/Frameworks/LaunchServices.framework/Support/lsregister -kill -r -domain local -domain system -domain user
{noformat}

However we need a way to resolve this more simply.
fields.summary: sourcetree:// links don't work if 1.4 was retrieved solely via direct auto-update

fields.description:
It appears that if there are no results from either  https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/users/<username/ or https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/user/follows/ then Bitbucket reports a simple message of 'Not Found' instead of returning an empty list. This breaks the JSON parsing that the SourceTree API interface expects.

BB's API should be more consistent, but we should try to cope with this to avoid problems.
fields.summary: Bitbucket API triggers JSON error when no results from lists

fields.description:
This is truly trivial and cosmetic, but it is one minor feature of MacHg that I miss when using SourceTree:

Would it be possible to propagate the file status icons (green checkmark for "clean", &c.) upwards to enclosing directories in the tree and (especially) column view?  This makes it quite easy to spot where changes have been made in a large project, without losing sight of the overall directory structure of the project (as happens in flat view).
fields.summary: Propagate file status icons "upwards" in tree/column view?

fields.description:
My global .gitconfig file contains lines similar to this:

[commit]
	template = /Users/kate.ebneter/.git_template.txt

When using command-line git, this causes the commit message to be populated with the contents of .git_template.txt. However, when committing via SourceTree, I get a blank commit message. It would be really nice if SourceTree honored this git setting.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't honor the commit.template setting in .gitconfig

fields.description:
In previous versions, when committing, the focus was on the commit message box and I could immediately begin to type my commit message and hit enter to commit.  Now, the focus is on the sign off checkbox, a box which I never wish to toggle.  

The commit message should be the star of the commit message dialog, not a the sign off checkbox.
fields.summary: Commit message dialog should focus on the commit message not the sign off checkbox.

fields.description:
The left side tags list is sorted incorrectly (compared to Mercurial tags command).

Consider the following tags list.  Sorted as per Mercurial (2.1):
1.1
1.2
1.9
1.10

SourceTree sorts the list in alpha-comparison order, making it difficult to find the most significant tag:
1.1
1.10
1.2
1.9

SourceTree should be sorting this list in numeric-comparison order, as Mercurial does.

The second part of this issue is that, when the tag list becomes significantly long (eg: 100+ tags), it will become practically impossible to use the tag list.

Providing options to:
* select the sort order (ascending/descending), and
* limit the list (most recent N tags)
will make this significantly more usable.
fields.summary: Tags list display sorting and filters

fields.description:
In 'Log View', it would be convenient to be able to create branch directly from context menu of a commit in the shown graph.

Currently options like Checkout..., Merge..., Rebase... and Tag... are shown, Create branch... would be a nice addition.
fields.summary: Add ability to create branch from commit

fields.description:
Thanks for great app. I want to use Japanese in the commit log, but the combining character string is difficult to read or not display at all.

I extract the commit objects from .git/objects and check the raw commit message bytes.

Original Message:
がぎぐげご

Commit from Git commandline: 
e3818c e3818e e38190 e38192 e38194

Commit from Github client:
e3818c e3818e e38190 e38192 e38194

Commit from SourceTree:
e3818b e38299 e3818d e38299 e3818f e38299 e38191 e38299 e38193 e38299

 * http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/304c/index.htm
 * http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/304b/index.htm
 * http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/3099/index.htm

 * http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakuten#Glyphs

> The combining characters are rarely used in full-width Japanese characters, as Unicode and all common multibyte Japanese encodings provide precomposed glyphs for all possible dakuten and handakuten character combinations in the standard hiragana and katakana ranges.
fields.summary: Unicode combining character is used to express Japanese 'Dakuten'.

fields.description: Reported by @PhillSparks, if you use the 'Install Command Line Tools' option and /usr/local doesn't already exist, the install fails silently. Need to create the folder structure if it's missing.
fields.summary: Command line tool install doesn't check if /usr/local exists, fails if not

fields.description: The default selection should be the same regardless of what row is selected in the log.
fields.summary: Git commit from log view on non-uncommitted line defaults to selected files, not staged changes

fields.description:
SourceTree already supports per-hunk and per-line staging/unstaging, and also supports 'Amend previous commit'. However one feature that GitX has is that when you click the 'Amend' checkbox, it displays all the previous changes in the 'Staged' box and allows you to unstage them (i.e. reverse apply them). This is pretty handy for cleaning up commits before pushing.

https://plus.google.com/u/0/110277469483406332394/posts/4m2tNzLmXHr

Without necessarily doing this exactly the same way, it would be useful to expose this functionality. A better way in fact would be to allow reverse-apply on any set of changes in the log, by hunk and by line (or by file). This could be used to undo changes more specifically than backing out an entire commit, can apply to both git and hg, and isn't limited to simply the previous commit.
fields.summary: Allow changes to be reverse applied from previous commit by hunk/line/file

fields.description: I get an error (See Screenshot_ if I try to stage a hunk with mnemonicprefix set to true.
fields.summary: Can't stage hunk with mnemonicprefix set to true

fields.description:
Since the pull dialog window is very small and cannot be resized, it's a bit hard to get an overview over incoming changes. 

Can you please make this window (and push as well) larger by default, and resizable (as is the case for eg. commit and tag).
fields.summary: Please make window for pull/push requests resizable (and larger by default)

fields.description:
After upgrading to 1.4.0b1, if I drag items around in the bookmark list under a group to reorder the way the items are listed, the reordering is not saved when the app is closed. When you next open the app, the items again appear in the original order. 

The default order does not appeare to be alphabetical either but it might be the order the items were created in.
fields.summary: Bookmark list does not remember item order

fields.description: Even though it's intended for the first run, any repos found during the setup wizard that are already bookmarked should always be ignored. Right now they're added to the import list so they will appear twice, this is an issue for people running through the setup wizard after having already used a previous version.
fields.summary: Find existing repos should always ignore already bookmarked paths

fields.description:
http://twitter.com/#!/chrisyipw/status/193309650853175296/photo/1/large

Seems like there's a limit to how large the underlying cell becomes, should remove that.
fields.summary: Max width in Bookmarks view stops buttons lining up

fields.description:
SourceTree currently doesn't expose the --signoff option in the Git commit window or in the Apply Patch window. These are tools often used by the open source community particularly and it's something you can't do without dropping to the command line right now. It's also not something that's easy to do via a Custom Action because of the need to provide other variable parameters such as the commit message.

Also need to expose the --author option in the case of commit.
fields.summary: Git signoff functionality (commit & apply)

fields.description:
See https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-963

New Current Branch filter will only show remote branches that are derivable from the local branch HEAD, therefore if the remote branch is ahead you won't be able to see it.

In order to support showing the tracked remote branch too, we need to derive what that is ahead of time and include it explicitly in the parameters to git log.
fields.summary: Add tracked remote branch to Current Branch filter if Show Remote Branches is enabled

fields.description: It would be great if when pulling the code from a branch you could see the progress and the speed in KB.
fields.summary: Pull progress information

fields.description:
If multiple commits are created with the same timestamp, either via 'git-svn dcommit' when there is more than one commit outstanding, or when using 'git rebase -i' to rewrite multiple changesets, if one of those commits is given a tag (or possibly a branch), git log is prone to reporting them out of order. Because the SourceTree log relies on a child commit being reported before its parent, this can cause incorrect graph rendering. 

A workaround for this is simply to select 'Ancestor Order' in the log options. This option is slower than the date order though, which is why it is not the default.

It would be nice to be able to detect this case and auto-enable the Ancestor Order option, although this will require the log to be completely refreshed. You can't actually tell that it's happened until you see a case where a parent commit has already been encountered by the time the child commit referring to it appears. Therefore we'd need to keep a running record of all the SHAs encountered so far. All these things have a performance impact which will need to be assessed, given that this doesn't happen very often and that the user can easily work around it with the Ancestor Order option already.

The other option might be to find a set of git log options which doesn't use --topo-order all the time but also doesn't report the commits out of order in this case. This will need to be carefully examined since the current commands issued already cope with a number of edge cases.
fields.summary: Git identical timestamps + tags can cause out of order commits from git log

fields.description:
If a git commit is created with --allow-empty (which is usually not recommended, see manual) this is not displayed correctly in the log detail. This is because the detail is retrieved from git diff-tree, which returns nothing.

This is an edge case, the git manual strongly suggests that you don't use --allow-empty. A user suggested that some changes to git in future might make this more common though, so if that's the case we may want to deal with this. git diff-tree was picked because it extracts the most amount of information most reliably in all situations except this one, may need to just use a fallback in this rare case.
fields.summary: Empty git commits are not displayed correctly
Current Branch + Show Remote Branches filter should show current branch and its corresponding remote branches

fields.description:
The new bookmark is great - but the font is a tad too bold and really stands out.
See screenshots

Might be nit-picking but I've not yet seen such strong fond in the options menu.
fields.summary: Could we change the font in the new bookmark options menu

fields.description: In addition to Git, Bitbucket and Klin, can external SVN access be added.  The company I work for uses an SVN server with personal certificated access.  The only GUI application that works with this is CornerStone.  I would love to move over to SourceTree, but I cannot until this feature is added.
fields.summary: External SVN Support

fields.description: I want to change branch name in source tree. Can we do that when we right click the branch?
fields.summary: Change branch name

fields.description:
When files are deleted from the working tree, provide an easy way to restore it from the "Files in working tree" view, file context menu.

This is the same as running git checkout -- $FILE (as git status recommends for this operation):
\# Changes not staged for commit:
\#   (use "git add/rm <file>..." to update what will be committed)
\#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
\#
\#	deleted:    foobar.txt

I can use a "Custom Action" (ie: git checkout -- $FILE), but it seems like this operation deserves it own built-in menu option.

(Workaround without making your own custom action is to stage it, then unstage it (which seems to effectively run git reset HEAD $FILE, which restores the file)).
fields.summary: Add context menu item to restore unstaged deletions

fields.description:
Currently source tree gets into strange states where the required steps to get out the state are not clear. Sometimes this even involves needing to hit cancel on a modal to avoid a "recursive loop".

It would be nice to get step by step instructions of how to deal with merge conflicts, or failed push/pull requests, etc
fields.summary: Better Merge/Conflict Handling

fields.description: Currently if I'm looking through the log I have to click on specific commits and look for the committer. It would be nice to have that in the table view
fields.summary: Add commiter to log view table

fields.description:
Add Bitbucket Issues service integration to SourceTree, allowing users to view create and modify issues on Bitbucket from the SourceTree app. There should be another view called Issues View that will show issues for the repository.

Start by adding Bitbucket Issues service and then maybe even Github Issues service. But please at least support Bitbucket Issues service.

This would be a great new feature for SourceTree. Because Bitbucket is part of Atlassian, getting approval should not be a problem.

Thank you so much for SourceTree! Thank you! Thank you!
fields.summary: Issues Service Integration (Jira)

fields.description:
Some users want to use SourceTree just as a viewer, from the terminal or from Finder, and don't want to either open previous windows on startup, nor do they want the bookmarks window displayed. Right now, if no repo windows are open on startup, or when the dock icon is clicked, the bookmarks window is shown. 

Offer an option in Preferences to stop that happening.
fields.summary: Add option to never open any windows on startup
Support subrepository remapping

fields.description: There are times you want to push and synch your svn-git combination even if you have uncommited changes, because you have some unfinished features or have some files you just doesn't want to push yet.
fields.summary: Make pushing to a remote svn possible, even if there are uncommited changes.

fields.description: It's really time intensive to ignore a buch of files with Sourcetree, because you can only select one file and ignore its exact filename. But if you want to have a couple of files ignored without a specific pattern, you have to touch every file.
fields.summary: Make ignoring files for a selection of multiple files possible

fields.description:
It would be nice if I am able to change the view of the Bookmarks on SourceTree. For example, I would like a list view of the repositories. This would be easier to see a condensed list of the repositories rather than having to scroll up and down.

Sorting options would also be nice on the Bookmarks. For example, it would be nice to sort the repositories by name or by date modified. It would also make it faster to find repositories from a large list.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Bookmarks List View and Sorting Options

fields.description:
Originally reported here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/44798/does-anyone-experience-the-branch-selector-hopping-around

When you use nested branches and then have a selection below this, on refresh the current selection jumps upwards by the number of items in the nested folder.
fields.summary: Sidebar selection jumping on refresh when using nested branch folders

fields.description: In the diff view, some long lines of code are wrapped and the remaining of the line becomes hidden (see the screen capture).
fields.summary: Long lines are wrapped and hidden in the diff view

fields.description:
Originally raised here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/39160/cannot-commit-to-a-mercurial-repo?page=1#43718

It appears that if you unshelve a change and choose not to delete it, when you next try to commit hg will try to open the editor (Vim by default) which fails because we're not in a terminal. So this is a state issue with hgattic which needs to be resolved.
fields.summary: hgattic prevents commits after applying a shelf without deleting it

fields.description: Sometimes in date view the parent commit for the commit you're looking at is a long ways away. It would be nice if the commit details area where Commit, Author, Date, etc... are listed would show the parent commit id and make it a clickable link that jumps to the parent commit. Like what gitk has.
fields.summary: Clickable parent id

fields.description: A git commit has a lot more metadata than is shown in the small box with the Commit, Author, Date, and Labels lines. Occasionally I'd like to be able to view this without dropping to the command line. Just like in Thunderbird (Command ⌘+U) I'd like to have some sort of "View Source" which would pop up and show me the raw data so I can inspect the metadata of the commit like I do the headers of an e-mail.
fields.summary: More commit details / View source window

fields.description: A git commit has a lot more metadata than is shown in the small box with the Commit, Author, Date, and Labels lines. Occasionally I'd like to be able to view this without dropping to the command line. Just like in Thunderbird (Command ⌘+U) I'd like to have some sort of "View Source" which would pop up and show me the raw data so I can inspect the metadata of the commit like I do the headers of an e-mail.
fields.summary: Details / Source view for commits

fields.description:
With keyboard focus on the list of changed files in a commit, you can press Space to QuickLook that file, which is great. However, at that point, the list of changed files loses focus, so you can't continue to use the up/down arrows to QuickLook other files in the list. Instead, you have to close the QuickLook window, press up or down arrow again, then press Space again.

Compare this behavior with Finder, where the list of files retains focus when the QuickLook window is open, and arrow key navigation allows you to easily QuickLook other files without closing the window first. This behavior would be good to have in SourceTree, too.
fields.summary: Quick Look shouldn't grab keyboard focus, if possible

fields.description:
Several of the projects I work use git repos to manage SVG graphics files. While browsing commits, SourceTree only shows the raw XML diffs for SVG files, which isn't very useful (to me). 

I can use QuickLook in the list of changed files to see the 'after' version, which is the next best thing. But it would be great if we could have full before/after preview of SVG files, like we do for other graphics files.
fields.summary: Graphical preview of SVG files would be useful

fields.description:
Requested by @littlefyr on Twitter, he'd like the ability to have prompts come up for parameters when a Custom Action is invoked, for cases where the parameters may vary per invocation.

He suggested quite a complex format for this including types, option lists and ranges but I think that's a bit overkill, and a simpler name/value association would work fine. So something like "$prompt(<name>)" where the dialog includes '<name>' as the parameter label.
fields.summary: Support parameter prompting in Custom Actions

fields.description: It would be very useful in the Mercurial Blame interface for a file to be able to see the date that the change was last made.  This should be a new column.
fields.summary: Blame - add date column

fields.description:
See:
http://screencast.com/t/0pBnkNrnd

It deletes the tag;
{code}
git -c core.quotepath=false tag -d t1 
Deleted tag 't1' (was 0a8bca5)
Completed successfully{code}
but when you do a push it adds it back again
{code}
git -c core.quotepath=false push -v --tags origin master:master 
Pushing to https://ajaynz@github.com/ajaynz/TEST.git
POST git-receive-pack (287 bytes)
To https://ajaynz@github.com/ajaynz/TEST.git

fields.summary: Can't delete a git TAG

fields.description: currently the very userful commit selected button only works in the file status view. however, it should also work in the log View when the uncommited changes are selected.
fields.summary: Commit Selected should work in the timelineview with the selected files in the lower pane

fields.description:
There is some confusion around the default behaviour of pushing a branch in git, compared to the pull tracking behaviour.

Tracking a remote branch in Git actually just means where you pull from. When pushing that branch with no specifics, it is assumed to be pushed to a branch of the same name on the remote, unless you configure 'remote.origin.push' to be something else (this is common for people who push via code review systems or deployment systems). 

Some people, especially those new to git might expect that if they chose to track a different branch, push would go back to that branch too (it doesn't). We can't change this default globally because it would be unexpected to git veterans. However, there should be some way we can make this more obvious or controllable. Options might include:

# When tracking a branch, if it's not the same name ask if the push option should be set too. However since push can be different per remote rather than just a single entry like pull tracking, this might be oversimplified.
# Have an extra section in the remote configuration where you specify the push behaviour. 

Git themselves may be changing the default behaviour: http://lwn.net/Articles/487131/ It is worth seeing what the outcome of this is before implementing any changes in SourceTree.
fields.summary: Git push defaults vs git pull tracking - resolve uncertainty

fields.description:
Scenario:

# You have a repository with a subrepo, but change the subrepo version that you're using in your working copy
# Someone else commits a change to the parent repository which tracks a different subrepo version
# You pull this commit into your own repo
# hg reports an error 'subrepository sources for X differ', expecting a terminal response to resolve the conflict, which is never received

Workaround:
Reverting the working copy to the tracked subrepo commit would allow the pull to proceed.

However, we should look out for this prompt and try to resolve it.
fields.summary: Cater for hg 'subrepository sources for X differ' message

fields.description:
Support for displaying Mercurial Bookmarks has been around for a while, but there is currently no interface for editing them. However, after only being requested rarely a year ago, I've had a couple of requests for this in the last week, so perhaps they are being used more now. Let's upvote this one and try to get it into 1.4 perhaps.

They're a bit like local branches in Git. Probably best to list them in the sidebar but under their own entry.
fields.summary: hg bookmarks support

fields.description:
Not sure if this is really a bug. Apologies if it's not.

I had about 30 local commits that were already rebased on top of the SVN tip. I pushed to the SVN remote. About half way through (12 or so commits already in SVN), another developer made a separate commit to SVN. His commit did not conflict with any changes in any of my commits. SourceTree managed to push one additional commit after his commit to SVN, and then stopped with this error:

{noformat}
git -c core.quotepath=false svn rebase

r10822 = 6781a19e5cb8bc934f5a6e7d3c830bf9f1eba082 (refs/remotes/git-svn)
W: 1f1543836ebe1005458ecc68ab33f61a6fb9cf7d and refs/remotes/git-svn differ, using rebase:
:040000 040000 2603c08f6f31a32718d9c337a6fcf2b8c39c4a30 ac525bae3d1db2ae94c3f0d9b34da9bd02d99ed3 M	ne
Cannot rebase: You have unstaged changes.
Please commit or stash them.
rebase refs/remotes/git-svn: command returned error: 1

Completed with errors, see above
{noformat}

In the above log output, r10821 is the other developers commit, and 10822 is the only one of my commits after his that succeeded before the error.

After this happened duplicated my whole git repository so I could try a few things. I tried to rebase my branch onto the new SVN tip, which seemed to cause a merge conflict for every commit when there was no actual conflict.

I tried to select all remaining commits that had not been pushed to SVN, then right clicked and selected "cherry pick". The dialogue seemed to be talking about check picking a single commit, even though I had selected several. After I confirmed I wanted to go ahead, there were a tonne of merge conflicts.

Finally I tried cherry picking each individual commit in sequence, and that worked. Then I was able to push to the SVN remote without any further errors.

Not sure why SourceTree (or Git) couldn't just rebase after the other developers commit and keep pushing, especially when his commit didn't even touch any of the files in any of my commits? The error says there were unstaged changes, but there were none when I started my push (SourceTree wouldn't let me push to SVN if I had unstaged changes).

Or why I couldn't "continue" the rebase, or start a new rebase operation without generating merge conflicts?

Or why I couldn't select a range of commits to cherry pick without generating merge conflicts, even though I could cherry pick each one manually?

Is this just the way Git is? When I start a push, it does a mixed reset to the SVN tip, stages changes for each commit in sequence? So when the remote had a different commit, it couldn't rebase? Couldn't Git (or SourceTree) just hard reset my working copy back to my branch automatically and start the rebase again?

What is the recommended way to recover from this situation?

Cheers.
fields.summary: 3rd party commit to SVN during large push to SVN remote causes push to fail.

fields.description:
If you specify an wrong user/pass for BitBucket Repo - Sourcetree throws a cryptic error: "lexical error: invalid char in json text."

This should be more meaningful
fields.summary: Throw a more meaningful error if using wrong credentials

fields.description: The commit list automatically refreshes every few seconds. After refresh the last commit of the currently selected branch (sidebar) gets focussed. This is quite annoying when trying to browse data of a commit that is not the lastest.
fields.summary: Refresh of commit list leads to lost focus

fields.description:
One thing I have found missing from just about every git client is an easy way to look at the history of a file as it applies in the current branch.  I.e., view every change leading up to the current state.

Perforce P4V has a time lapse view of the file which is just phenomenal for this type of exploration.

Tower has a more basic feature that allows you to open a diff window of the single file and select revisions to compare from a drop down.
fields.summary: File History View ala Tower File History or Perforce Time Lapse

fields.description:
I use SourceTree heavily for cherry-picking, mainly for Sinatra and Rack maintenance.

This involves me being on one release branch, for instance 1.3.x and going through commits on another branch, like master. However, I can only either few the history of the currently checked out branch or of all local branches (or of all branches). Just seing all the local branches in an overkill already, since I usually have multiple actively maintained branches (3 for Sinatra, 5 for Rack at the moment).

So it would be handy to be able to filter what branches should be displayed independently from the currently checked out branch.

It would also be handy to somehow make it easier to see a difference between merge commits and normal commits, esp. when scanning long, complex commit histories (say, either not list merge commits or use grey text instead of black or something similar).

I know this would probably be only useful to power users like me, but this is one of the few places where I really see an advantage of a UI like SourceTree over using the command line client.
fields.summary: Enhance log filtering

fields.description:
Both Tower and "GitHub for Mac" supports protocol handlers, to open a repo by clicking the link:

Tower: gittower://openRepo/
GitHub mac: github-mac://openRepo/

Example: github-mac://openRepo/https://github.com/sindresorhus/GitHub-Notifier

SourceTree needs to have this too.
fields.summary: Protocol handler

fields.description:
I often find myself in a situation where: On branch A, make some changes, commit the good ones, and ignore some debug code that doesn't need to be in the production app. Then I want to switch to branch B. It tells me that the changes to the following files would be overwitten by the checkout. My only option is to "Close" the error dialog.* Then I repeat, this time checking the checkbox.

*At that point it would be nice to have the options of "Overwrite" and "Close".

Whenever switching branches, the user is presented with a checkbox "Discard local changes." That triggers the overwrite behavior desired above, but "Discard" sounds so destructive, I often don't click it and much of the time the branch switch completes, even if there are minor changes.

If those two options were added to the error dialog, it might make the "Confirm Branch Switch" dialog unnecessary. It would either be a clean switch, or the user would be asked if they want to continue, knowing what files would be affected.

(Love the app, by the way)
fields.summary: Switching from a dirty branch could be made easier

fields.description:
Redmin provides an atom feed of all of the issues in a project.  I'd like to be able to attach that feed toa repository in SourceTree so that I can then select an issue to reference in a commit message as well as have SourceTree detect those references if a feed has been set up and automatically link them from the commit log to the original issue in Redmine.  Here's a sample of an individual bug in the atom feed:

{code:xml}
<entry>
<title>Task #3756 (Resolved): Jan Leads Report</title>
<link href="https://bugs.example.com/issues/3756" rel="alternate"/>
<id>https://bugs.example.com/issues/3756</id>
<updated>2012-02-06T23:26:20+01:00</updated>
<author>
<name>Example User</name>
<email>example@example.com</email>
</author>
<content type="html"></content>
</entry>
{code}

All of the XML seems pretty standard and should be fairly easy to parse.  I would imagine others have a similar structure but it could be done as some kind of plugin architecture so people can define the mapping manually and then release them back into the wild for others to use.
fields.summary: Integrate with 3rd party issues tracker that provide atom/rss feeds

fields.description:
Originally raised: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-114

This was probably caused by the simplification of the push dialog to avoid remote checking. It appeared that without the remote checking we had to derive the remote matches ourselves, because 'git remote show' only reports correct details when checking the remote.

Need to find a way to respect "https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-114" without querying the remote. Should be possible since the configuration is local, but it depends on whether git commands report it or whether we have to specifically check for it.
fields.summary: Git push dialog should respect git config "push = refs/heads/*:refs/for/*"

fields.description:
https://skitch.com/chrisyip/8eycc/sourcetree

The 'Select All' box should stay in sync with the actual selections, so unchecking if a subset is then checked and so on.
fields.summary: Git push branch - 'Select All' doesn't stay in sync

fields.description: The search view should provide feedback when a search has been submitted. It could display an indicator while the search is still running. Also, when no items have been found there could be a message (maybe in the result list or in the status bar at the bottom).
fields.summary: Search should provide feedback

fields.description:
Basically I have SourceTree open with the Bookmarks-window. It would be cool to be able to open the local directory (working copy) of a repository from this window. Something like double-, Cmd-, Alt-click the bookmark, context-menu (would allow to add some other actions) or simply add a button "Open in finder".


Btw: I came from the Mac App Store by clicking the support-link and following the link for requesting a new feature that led me here. First I had to register - YAFA: Yet Another Fucking Account. After that I had to search the project and find out how to search for feature-issues to see if I could support a feature request (didn't find one). Long story short: It's pretty difficult to put a feature-suggestion here...
fields.summary: Open repository location in finder from Bookmarks-view
